case_name: Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay v. Workmen

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 621 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No 621 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal brought by special leave from the Award dated January 15, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal. by special leave from the Award dated January 15, 1960, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay,

facts.text: Award issued by the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference No. 94 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: from the Award dated January 15, 1960, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay, in Reference T.  No. 94 of 1959,

facts.text: Appellant is Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents, the workmen of the appellant companypany, the Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay,

facts.text: Respondents are the workmen of the appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: Two demands made by the respondents, the workmen of the appellant companypany,

facts.text: Two demands made by respondents: gratuity and provident fund.

anchor.surface_text: Two demands made by the respondents, the workmen of the appellant companypany, the Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay, were referred for industrial adjudication

facts.text: Demands referred to Industrial Tribunal under s. 12 5 of the Industrial Disputes Act, XIV of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the Garment Cleaning Works, Bombay, were referred for industrial adjudication to the industrial tribunal under s. 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act,

facts.text: Tribunal framed a gratuity scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The tribunal has framed a gratuity scheme and has passed an order that the appellant should draw up a scheme

facts.text: Tribunal ordered appellant to draw up provident fund scheme on lines of model scheme under Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952, with company contribution of 6 1/4 per cent of total wages.

anchor.surface_text: a gratuity scheme and has passed an order that the appellant should draw up a scheme of provident fund on the lines of the model provident fund scheme drawn by the Government under the Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952  XIX of 1952 , with a rate of companytribution of 6 1/4 per cent. of total wages.

facts.text: Appellant challenges gratuity scheme and provident fund directions by appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Both the gratuity scheme as drawn up and the directions as to the drawing up of a provident fund scheme are challenged by the appellant by its present appeal which it has brought to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Petitioner argued gratuity scheme should be considered on industry-cum-region basis.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the direction as to the gratuity scheme the argument which has been urged before us by Mr. Sen is that the problem of starting such a scheme should have been companysidered on an industry-cum-region basis

facts.text: Gratuity scheme Clause ii a provides gratuity on retirement or resignation after ten years service at ten days consolidated wages per year.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  ii   a  of the gratuity scheme provides that on retirement or resignation of a workman after ten years service ten days companysolidated wages for each years service should be awarded as gratuity.

facts.text: Petitioner contended no gratuity under Clause ii a unless fifteen years service.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen quarrels with this provision.He companytends that numbergratuity should be admissible under this clause until and unless fifteen years service has been put in by the employee.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme Clause iv: if dismissed or discharged for misconduct causing financial loss, gratuity to extent of loss not paid.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  iv  is then challenged by Mr. Sen. This clause provides that if a workman is dismissed or discharged for misconduct causing financial loss to the works gratuity to the extent of the loss should number be paid

facts.text: Petitioner contended Clause iv inconsistent with gratuity principles, no gratuity for misconduct.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen companytends that this clause is inconsistent with the principles on which gratuity claims are generally based. Gratuity which is in the nature of retrial benefit is based on long and meritorious service,

facts.text: Gratuity scheme Clause v: entire service of workmen taken into account for calculating years of service.

anchor.surface_text: The last companytention raised by Mr. Sen in regard to the gratuity scheme has reference to cl.  v  of the scheme. This clause provides that for calculating years of service the entire service

facts.text: Petitioner contended service in clauses i, ii, iii refers to continuous service; position not disputed by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen companytends that though the word companytinuous has number been used either in cl.  v  or in clauses  i ,  ii  and  iii  we should make it clear that the service referred to in all the said clauses referred to companytinuous service. This position is number disputed by Mr. Dudhia

facts.text: Appellant produced balance-sheet and papers, claimed privilege under s. 21 of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that when the appellant produced its balance-sheet and other relevant papers it claimed privilege under s. 21 of the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Tribunal examined financial figures but could not discuss them in award due to privilege.

anchor.surface_text: Inevitably the Tribunal companyld number discuss the figures disclosed by the said books in its award though it must have examined the said figures carefully.

facts.text: Tribunal concluded appellant has good profits, assured future, capacity to build reserves.

anchor.surface_text: It has observed that the question to companysider in framing the provident fund scheme is whether the employer has made good profits, whether its future is assured, whether it has capacity to build up adequate reserves. Having thus posed the question the Tribunal ha,-, companye to the companyclusion that the appellant satisfies all these requirements.

facts.text: Petitioner contended tribunal did not assess financial obligation and capacity properly; appellant has no reserve, borrowed large loans.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen companytends that in issuing this direction the tribunal has number properly assessed the extent of the financial obligation which the scheme would impose upon the appellant and the limited nature of its financial capacity. ... Mr. Sen companytends that the tribunal did number take into account the fact that the appellant has numberreserve, and that it had borrowed large loans.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J. on April 3, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, J.-Two demands made by the respondents,

facts.text: Petitioner requested remand for reconsideration of financial capacity without claiming privilege.

anchor.surface_text: He, therefore, faintly suggested that we may remand the case subject to any order as to companyts that we may deem fit to make and ask the Tribunal to reconsider the matter in the light of the relevant documents, and he assured us that he would number claim privilege under s. 21 after remand.

facts.text: Court refused to interfere with tribunal's direction on provident fund scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore we see numberreason to interfere with the direction given by the Tribunal in regard to the framing of the provident fund scheme.

facts.text: Court clarified that service in gratuity clauses i, ii, iii refers to continuous service.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly make it clear that the service referred to in clauses  i ,  ii  and  iii  refers to companytinuous service.
Appeal. by special leave from the Award dated January 15, 1960, of the Industrial Tribunal, Bombay,
under s. 12 5  of the Industrial Disputes Act, XIV of 1947. These demands were for gratuity and provident fund respectively.

issues.text: Whether the problem of starting a gratuity scheme should have been considered on an industry-cum-region basis

anchor.surface_text: the problem of starting such a scheme should have been companysidered on an industry-cum-region basis and companysiderations relevant

issues.text: Whether gratuity is admissible on resignation after 10 years service under clause ii(a) of the gratuity scheme or only after 15 years

anchor.surface_text: Clause  ii   a  of the gratuity scheme provides that on retirement or resignation of a workman after ten years service ten days companysolidated wages for each years service should be awarded as gratuity. Mr. Sen quarrels with this provision.He companytends that numbergratuity should be admissible under this clause until and unless fifteen years service has been put in by the employee.

issues.text: Whether clause iv of the gratuity scheme is valid, or gratuity should be fully forfeited on dismissal for misconduct

anchor.surface_text: Gratuity which is in the nature of retrial benefit is based on long and meritorious service, and the argument is that if the service of an employee is terminated on the ground of misconduct it would number be open to him on principle to claim gratuity because misconduct puts a blot on the character of his service and that disqualifies him from any claim of gratuity.

issues.text: Whether the service referred to in clauses i, ii and iii of the gratuity scheme refers to continuous service

anchor.surface_text: The last companytention raised by Mr. Sen in regard to the gratuity scheme has reference to cl.  v  of the scheme.

arguments.court_reasoning: Request untenable; privilege claimed at trial, cannot waive post-trial for reconsideration

holdings.text: Gratuity scheme can be framed on unit basis; industry-cum-region basis is permissible but not the only or mandatory basis.

anchor.surface_text: it is clear that it is one thing to hold that the gratuity scheme can in a proper case be framed on industry- cum-region basis, and another thing to say that industry-cum-region basis is the only basis on which gratuity scheme can be framed. In fact, in a large majority of cases gratuity schemes are drafted on the basis of the units and it has never been suggested or held that such schemes are not permissible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bharatkhand Textile case held industry-cum-region permissible but not mandatory; unit basis common and valid.

holdings.text: Provision in clause ii(a) prescribing gratuity on resignation after 10 years service is not unreasonable and cannot be successfully challenged.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the observation on which this argument is based was not intended to lay down a rule of universal application in regard to all gratuity schemes, and so it cannot be made the basis of an attack against a gratuity scheme where instead of fifteen years service 10 years minimum service is prescribed to enable an employee to claim gratuity at the rate determined if he resigns after ten years, service. Therefore, we do not think that the provision of cl. ii a can be successfully challenged as being unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Express Newspapers observation not universal rule; 10 years minimum permissible.

holdings.text: Clause iv of gratuity scheme valid; gratuity earned for service rendered payable despite dismissal for misconduct except to extent of financial loss caused.

anchor.surface_text: On principle if gratuity is earned by an employee for long and meritorious service it is difficult to understand why the benefit thus earned by long and meritorious service should not be available to the employee even though at the end of such service lie may have been found guilty of misconduct which entails his dismissal. Gratuity is not paid to the employee gratuitously or merely as a matter of boon. It is paid to him for the service rendered by him to the employer, and when it is once earned it is difficult to understand why it should necessarily be denied to him whatever may be the nature of misconduct for his dismissal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gratuity deferred earnings for service, not gratuitous; full forfeiture unjust; retrenchment compensation and PF deductions distinguished as not fully forfeiting earned benefits; common tribunal practice to limit forfeiture to loss.

holdings.text: Service referred to in clauses i, ii and iii of gratuity scheme refers to continuous service.

anchor.surface_text: We would accordingly make it clear that the service referred to in clauses i , ii and iii refers to continuous service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's contention accepted as not disputed by respondents.

holdings.text: No interference with tribunal's direction on provident fund scheme; tribunal properly assessed financial capacity; no remand for reconsideration without privilege claim.

anchor.surface_text: This request is plainly untenable. If the appellant wanted the tribunal to consider the figures and state its conclusions in the light of the said figures in its award it need not have claimed privilege under s. 21 at the trial. It is not too late to suggest that the privilege be waived and that the matter be considered afresh by the tribunal or by us in the appeal. Therefore we see no reason to interfere with the direction given by the Tribunal in regard to the framing of the provident fund scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant claimed privilege under s.21 preventing discussion; cannot seek remand post-trial to waive privilege; tribunal examined figures and found capacity based on profits, assured future, reserve-building ability.

precedents.citation: The Bharatkhand Textile Mfg. Co. Ltd. Ors. v. The Textile Labour Association, Ahmedabad 1 19603 S.C.R. 329

anchor.surface_text: The Bharatkhand Textile Mfg. Co. Ltd. Ors. v. The Textile Labour Association, Ahmedabad 1 . In that case the industrial companyrt had numberdoubt dealt with a claim for gratuity made by the workmen on the industry-cum-region basis, and an attack against the validity of the said approach made by the employer in regard to the scheme was repelled by this Court. It would, however, be numbericed that all that this Court decided in that case was that it was erroneous to companytend that a gratuity scheme companyld never be based on industry- cum-region basis, and in support of this companyclusion several companysiderations were set forth in the 1 19603 S.C.R. 329.

precedents.case_name: Bharatkhand Textile Mfg Co Ltd v Textile Labour Association Ahmedabad
precedents.cited_proposition: gratuity scheme should be considered on an industry-cum-region basis

precedents.citation: The Express Newspapers Private Ltd. Anr. v. The Union of India Ors. 2 1959 S.C.R. 12, 154

anchor.surface_text: the case of The Express Newspapers Private Ltd. Anr. v. The Union of India Ors. 2 . In that case the provisions of s. 5 1 a iii of the Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 45 of 1955 , was struck down on the ground that its provisions violated the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19 l g The companyclusion of this Court was that the provision for gratuity made by the said clause to an employee who had put in three years service imposes an unreasonable restriction on the employers right to carry on business and is therefore liable to be struck down as unconstitutional. Dealing with that provision this Court incidentally observed that where the employee has been in companytinuous service of the employer for a period of more than fifteen years he would be entitled to gratuity on his resigning his post.

precedents.case_name: Express Newspapers Pvt Ltd v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: employee entitled to gratuity on resignation only after fifteen years continuous service
precedents.cited_holding: observation that employee with more than fifteen years service entitled to gratuity on resignation

outcome.relief_summary: Gratuity scheme upheld with clarification that service in clauses i, ii and iii refers to continuous service; no interference with provident fund scheme direction
directions: the service referred to in clauses i, ii and iii refers to continuous service

anchor.surface_text: it is clear that it is one thing to hold that the gratuity scheme can in a proper case be framed on industry- cum-region basis, and another thing to say that industry-cum-region basis is the only basis on which gratuity scheme can be framed. In fact, in a large majority of cases gratuity schemes are drafted on the basis of the units and it has never been suggested or held that such schemes are not permissible.

it is clear that it is one thing to hold that the gratuity scheme can in a proper case be framed on industry- cum-region basis, and another thing to say that industry-cum-region basis is the only basis on which gratuity scheme can be framed. anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the observation on which this argument is based was not intended to lay down a rule of universal application in regard to all gratuity schemes, and so it cannot be made the basis of an attack against a gratuity scheme where instead of fifteen years service 10 years minimum service is prescribed to enable an employee to claim gratuity at the rate determined if he resigns after ten years, service. Therefore, we do not think that the provision of cl. ii a can be successfully challenged as being unreasonable.

In our opinion, the observation on which this argument is based was not intended to lay down a rule of universal application in regard to all gratuity schemes, and so it cannot be made the basis of an attack against a gratuity scheme where instead of fifteen years service 10 years minimum service is prescribed to enable an employee to claim gratuity at the rate determined if he resigns after ten years, service. Therefore, we do not think that the provision of cl. ii a can be successfully challenged as being unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: On principle if gratuity is earned by an employee for long and meritorious service it is difficult to understand why the benefit thus earned by long and meritorious service should not be available to the employee even though at the end of such service lie may have been found guilty of misconduct which entails his dismissal. Gratuity is not paid to the employee gratuitously or merely as a matter of boon. It is paid to him for the service rendered by him to the employer, and when it is once earned it is difficult to understand why it should necessarily be denied to him whatever may be the nature of misconduct for his dismissal.

On principle if gratuity is earned by an employee for long and meritorious service it is difficult to understand why the benefit thus earned by long and meritorious service should not be available to the employee even though at the end of such service lie may have been found guilty of misconduct which entails his dismissal. anchor.surface_text: This request is plainly untenable. If the appellant wanted the tribunal to consider the figures and state its conclusions in the light of the said figures in its award it need not have claimed privilege under s. 21 at the trial. It is not too late to suggest that the privilege be waived and that the matter be considered afresh by the tribunal or by us in the appeal. Therefore we see no reason to interfere with the direction given by the Tribunal in regard to the framing of the provident fund scheme.

This request is plainly untenable. If the appellant wanted the tribunal to consider the figures and state its conclusions in the light of the said figures in its award it need not have claimed privilege under s. 21 at the trial. It is not too late to suggest that the privilege be waived and that the matter be considered afresh by the tribunal or by us in the appeal. Therefore we see no reason to interfere with the direction given by the Tribunal in regard to the framing of the provident fund scheme.
